"Whether you subpoenaed 10 people or 10,000, including her was simply not right." He also told lawmakers that "each and every one of you owes nothing less than truth and accuracy to the American people".

The couple were subpoenaed by the Republican chair of the House of Representatives' oversight committee - James Comer.

In a social media post which shared the opening statement, Bill Clinton wrote: "As someone who grew up in a home with domestic abuse, not only would I not have flown on his plane if I had any inkling of what he was doing—I would have turned him in myself and led the call for justice for his crimes, not sweetheart deals."

Clinton also said he had "no idea of the crimes Epstein was committing" before adding: "No matter how many photos you show me, I have two things that at the end of the day matter more than your interpretation of those 20-year-old photos.

"I know what I saw, and more importantly, what I didn't see. I know what I did, and more importantly, what I didn't do. I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong."

This is a breaking news story.

News.title: 'Unbreakable' code baffled detectives investigating mystery of MI6 spy found dead in bag
News.content:
'Unbreakable' code baffled detectives investigating mystery of MI6 spy found dead in bag

MI6 prodigy Gareth Williams, 31, was found dead inside a padlocked bag in a Pimlico flat used to house intelligence workers - and new questions have been raised about the police's investigation

View 3 Images MI6 code breaker Gareth Williams, 31, was found dead inside a sports bag in his flat (Image: PA)

Detectives investigating the mysterious death of an MI6 spy mistakenly identified the name of a Welsh mountain as a secret code, it has been claimed.

‌



The decomposing body of the 31-year-old mathematics prodigy Gareth Williams was discovered padlocked inside a red North Face bag in the bathtub of his Pimlico flat in August 2010 - sparking a major investigation that saw Scotland Yard given unprecedented access to the secret services.

‌



During the investigation, officers searching Mr Williams' diary uncovered a jumbled phrase they believed to be an 'uncrackable' cipher that could offer key clues over the events leading up to his death.

‌



UK diplomats rushed out of base in Israel after Middle East security fears READ MORE :

View 3 Images A reconstruction of a man locking himself in a sports holdall was shown to the jury during the inquest (Image: PA)

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings

‌



However, when they presented the note to the dead man's friends, it was quickly identified as 'Cadair Idris' - a mountain in Wales - written in his native Welsh . A source close to the family noted that Mr Williams was training for the Snowdon marathon at the time .

They described the error as one of several "embarrassing failures" in the police investigation, telling MailOnline: "That just shows you how useless they were" . Mr Williams was found naked inside the holdall, which had been fastened with a padlock from the outside, while the key was found underneath his body .

The flat, which is often used by intelligence staff, had the heating turned on full blast, despite it being the middle of summer, and there were no fingerprints found on the bag, padlock, or bath. In 2012, coroner Fiona Wilcox concluded that the death of Mr Williams, a GCHQ worker on secondment to MI6, was "unnatural and likely to have been criminally mediated" and that a third party may have been involved in moving the bag into the bath.

‌



View 3 Images CCTV image of Gareth Williams at Holland Park Tube station two days before his death (Image: PA)

But Scotland Yard concluded that Williams most likely died alone after accidentally locking himself inside the bag. A forensic review reopened in 2021 was closed in 2024, with police stating it identified no further lines of inquiry to disprove their main theory. To this day, critics cast doubt on the narrative that Mr Williams acted alone.

Confined space rescue specialist Peter Faulding claimed he had tried "300 times" to replicate locking the bag from the inside without leaving forensic traces and failed, calling the police's solo-death theory a "physical impossibility".

‌



He told the Mail: "My belief is that the bag was placed in the bath with Gareth dead already. Even if he could get in the bag, and even if he then padlocked it from the inside, there would be footprints and fingerprints all over the bath and the bag."

The Met Police told the Mirror today that while the force is not reopening the case, any new evidence will be reviewed by specialist detectives should it come to light, as is the case with all unexplained deaths.

A spokesperson said: “Our thoughts remain with Gareth’s family who continue to grieve his loss. Since 2010, we have carried out extensive enquiries into Gareth’s death which has seen officers collect and review a significant amount of material and statements.

Article continues below

“As part of our investigation, officers also conducted a three-year forensic review. This was a thorough and in-depth process, which concluded in 2024 and identified no further lines of enquiry.

“As with all unexplained deaths, any new information or evidence will be reviewed by specialist detectives should it come to light.”

News.title: Bill Clinton says 'I saw nothing' in first statement on Jeffrey Epstein links
News.content:
Bill Clinton says 'I saw nothing' in first statement on Jeffrey Epstein links

Bill Clinton has made an opening statement as he testifies to a congressional panel ‌about his links to the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

The former US president vehemently denied having any knowledge of the crimes Epstein had been committing, telling the House Overnight Committee: "I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong." He also said "I would have turned him in myself" if he had any inkling of what was going on.

"I had no idea of the crimes Epstein was committing," Clinton said. "No matter how many photos you show me, I have two things that at the end of the day matter more than your interpretation of those 20-year-old photos.

"I know what I saw, and more importantly, what I didn't see. I know what I did, and more importantly, what I didn't do. I saw nothing, and I did nothing wrong."

Image: AP) AP)

The statement comes after the former president was pictured multiple times in the first batch of files released by the Department of Justice in January, including a picture of him swimming in a pool, and another which showed him lying back with his hands behind his head in a hot tub.

Other photos show him with women whose faces have been redacted. He has not been accused of wrongdoing in his relationship with Epstein, and appearing in the files does not imply wrongdoing.

His opening statement continued: "As someone who grew up in a home with domestic abuse, not only would I not have flown on his plane if I had any inkling of what he was doing - I would have turned him in myself and led the call for justice for his crimes, not sweetheart deals."

Yesterday, Hillary Clinton was questioned about her feelings over claims young women had massaged her husband, a source told CNN.

Image: Getty Images) Getty Images)

Sources said Mrs Clinton replied that she would not speculate about things she was not present for - and that she was not there to talk about feelings. Defending his wife today, Bill told the committee that including Hillary in the discussion about Epstein "was simply not right".

He said "I have to get personal. You made Hillary come in. She had nothing to do with Jeffrey Epstein. She has no memory of even meeting him.

"She neither travelled with him nor visited any of his properties. Whether you subpoenaed 10 people or 10,000, including her was simply not right."

Bill said his "brief acquaintance" with Epstein ended "years before" Epstein's crimes came to light.

"Though I never witnessed during our limited interactions any indication of what was truly going on, I am here to offer what little I know so that it might prevent anything like this from every happening again," he said.

Clinton flew on Epstein's plane multiple times in the early 2000s after serving as US president from 1993 to 2001. He expressed regret for his association and said he ended contact with Epstein long before his 2008 guilty plea came to light.

"But even with 20/20 hindsight, I saw nothing that ever gave me pause," he said during his opening statement.

"We are only here because he hid it from everyone so well for so long. And by the time it came to light with his 2008 guilty plea, I had long stopped associating with him."

News.title: Ian Huntley 'refuses prison food' over poisoning fears and 'living on diet of Wotsits'
News.content:
EXCLUSIVE: Ian Huntley 'refuses prison food' over poisoning fears and 'living on diet of Wotsits'

Ian Huntley was paranoid about being 'poisoned' by fellow inmates before he was attacked and left fighting for life in hospital, as the Soham killer remains in serious condition

View 7 Images Ian Huntley after being treated in 2005 (Image: Daily Mirror)

Ian Huntley was paranoid about being 'poisoned' by fellow inmates before he was attacked and left fighting for life in hospital.

‌



The Soham killer remained in a serious condition today after an inmate battered him around the head with a metal bar. He was left in a pool of blood in a workshop at HMP Frankland on Thursday morning.

‌



Police and prison authorities have not confirmed the identity of the suspect, named as triple killer Anthony Russell. Huntley, who worked as a cleaner on A wing at Frankland, had given up prison food because he was so convinced his fellow inmates were "out to get him."

‌



He had been attacked before at Frankland, and HMP Wakefield, where he also attempted to take his own life in 2005.

View 7 Images Ian Huntley after a failed suicide bid in Wakefield jail in 2005 (Image: Daily Mirror)

Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings

‌



Instead, he bought fast food and confectionery from the shop, causing his weight to balloon.

"He has been living on a diet of things like cheesy Wotsits," a source said. "He would not eat the prison food because he was convinced an inmate would poison him. So he bought snack food from the shop so he knew exactly what he was eating."

Durham Police said there has been no change in the 52-year-old’s condition overnight. "He remains in hospital in a serious condition," said their spokesperson.

‌



View 7 Images Huntley was attacked on Thursday morning (Image: Unknown)

Huntley is serving a life sentence for the murders of 10-year-olds Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman after they left a family barbecue to buy sweets in Soham, Cambridgeshire, on August 4 2002.

He dumped their bodies in a ditch and fell under suspicion after giving media interviews about the police investigation. He is serving a minimum 40-year term and has become an increasingly isolated figure behind bars.

‌



View 7 Images Anthony Russell reportedly attacked Ian Huntley at HMP Frankland (Image: West Midlands Police)

"He does not look like the man we saw on TV all those years ago," the source added. "He is much, much heavier, his weight has ballooned because of his diet." Huntley, like many long term prisoners, had tried various ploys to improve his regime.

He worked as a cleaner on the wing so that staff could closely monitor him. He is held alongside others at risk of attack and kept apart from the rest of the prison population. But his attacker struck "when it was least expected", according to insiders.

‌



View 7 Images Durham's Frankland jail (Image: PA)

"Huntley's wing is like a prison within a prison," they added. "Some inmates there convert to Islam because the food is meant to be better. They also think the regime allows more time out of the cell to pray. They say the food is like having a takeaway."

Huntley was attacked with a 'heavy metal bar' just after 9am on Thursday. He was battered so violently around the head that there were fears for his life. He has been attacked three times while behind bars and has twice attempted suicide.

‌



View 7 Images Huntley was jailed for the murders of Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman in 2002 (Image: Shutterstock)

"He knew that he was a target," added a source. "That is why he was so paranoid about his food." The bodies of Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman were found two weeks after they disappeared in August 2002.

Huntley was convicted in December 2003 following a trial at the Old Bailey. His girlfriend Maxine Carr, a teaching assistant at the girls' primary school, was also jailed in 2003 after being found guilty of conspiring to pervert the course of justice.

‌



View 7 Images Police sealed off Huntley's home, which he shared with Maxine Carr (Image: PA)

She was freed from jail and given a new identity in May 2004. After his arrest, it emerged Huntley had been able to work with children despite facing rape and sexual assault complaints.

He had been the subject of a series of allegations made to police in Humberside, where he previously worked. A subsequent inquiry led to criminal checks on anyone working with children.

Article continues below

Huntley was scalded with boiling water at HMP Wakefield in 2005. He was moved to Frankland, where robber Damien Fowkes slashed him in 2010. The wound was 7in (18cm) long and required 21 stitches. Fowkes asked a prison officer: "Is he dead? I hope so."

News.title: UK diplomats rushed out of base in Israel after Middle East security fears
News.content:
UK diplomatic staff and their dependents have been moved from Tel Aviv to another location in Israel, the Foreign Office has said amid mounting concern about the security situation in the Middle East.

British citizens have meanwhile been advised to avoid all but essential travel to Israel.

It comes after the Foreign Office "temporarily" withdrew its staff from Iran amid the threat of US strikes against the country.

An update to official travel advice said: “Due to the ongoing security situation, we have taken the precautionary measure to temporarily withdraw UK staff from Iran.”

It added that the British embassy “continues to operate remotely” after it was closed in mid-January.

Yesterday, Prime Minister Keir Starmer said the UK was focused on “supporting the political process” between the US and Iran as Donald Trump prepares for a large-scale missile attack on the country.

Number 10 is reported to have blocked a request from Trump to use the Diego Garcia base in the Chagos Islands in the event that he decides to launch a military campaign against Iran, due to concerns it would breach international law.

On February 19, Trump gave Iran 10 to 15 days to make a "meaningful deal" to cease all development of nuclear technology, which he claims they continue to invest in despite joint Israeli-US strikes last summer on key sites.

Image: AP) AP)

High-level talks between US and Iran have since been held in Geneva, with mediators from Oman yesterday hailing "significant progress" but admitting no major breakthroughs in reaching a deal to avert war.

US cargo planes, fighter jets and refuelling tankers have been tracked moving to the region in recent weeks, while a second aircraft carrier is being moved across the Mediterrenean. The 1,106ft aircraft carrier USS Gerald R Ford left Crete yesterday, and is expected to arrive off the coast of Israel in the coming hours - primed for a potential weekend strike on Iran.

In a warning to Tehran's leadership during his State of the Union address on Wednesday, Trump said: "My preference is to solve this problem through diplomacy. But one thing is certain, I will never allow the world’s number one sponsor of terror, which they are, by far, to have a nuclear weapon. Can’t let that happen"

“They’re starting it all over. We wiped it out, and they want to start all over again, and are at this moment, again, pursuing their sinister ambitions. We are in negotiations with them. They want to make a deal, but we haven’t heard those secret words: ‘We will never have a nuclear weapon’,”

News.title: Ian Huntley's sick 'prison nod' to Holly and Jessica and warped penpal request
News.content:
Ian Huntley's sick 'prison nod' to Holly and Jessica and warped penpal request

Notorious murderer Ian Huntley is fighting for his life after a brutal attack by a fellow inmate at HMP Frankland -

View 2 Images Ian Huntley was attacked in prison yesterday (Image: Alamy Stock Photo)

Ian Huntley has been given a 5 percent chance of survival after being bludgeoned with a metal spike in jail for his crimes. The attack reportedly ended with him being "ripped apart like a rat" is suspected to have been committed by a triple murderer who raped a pregnant woman in the prison workshop.

‌



Huntley, 52, became one of the UK's most notorious murderers after he was convicted for killing 10 year old best friends Jessica Chapman and Holly Wells - a case that shocked the nation. He was working at the time as a school caretaker, despite previous allegations of sexual violence against young women and teenage girls. The sinister killer even joined in the search for the two girls and took part in media interviews when 400 police officers descended on the sleepy Cambridgeshire town of Soham.

‌



He has been serving his sentence at the Category A prison HMP Frankland in County Durham since 2008. Dubbed 'Monster Mansion' the prison's inmates have a fearsome reputation, and the number one suspect in the attack, Anthony Russell, is no exception. He was convicted in 2022 for the murder of Julie Williams and her son David and horrific rape and murder of Nicole McGregor, who was pregnant at the time, in a terrifying week-long crime spree near Leamington Spa in 2020 - he is serving a whole life order for his crimes.

‌



Ensure our latest headlines always appear at the top of your Google Search by making us a Preferred Source. Click here to activate or add us as your Preferred Source in your Google search settings.

Ian Huntley's chilling letter to daughter after she discovered who he was READ MORE :

Maxine Carr's life now married in seaside town as Ian Huntley fights for life READ MORE :

View 2 Images Anthony Russell allegedly attacked Ian Huntley at HMP Frankland (Image: West Midlands Police)

Ashley is alleged to have said, "I've done it, I've done it. I've killed him, I've killed him," as he was taken away handcuffed. Huntley was airlifted to a nearby hospital for treatment and was, a source said, in a "terrible state".

‌



The Soham killer has never been popular with his fellow inmates, and this is not the first time he has been attacked. Back in 2005, whilst at HMP Wakefield, convicted mass murderer Mark Hobson attacked Huntley with boiling water, and in 2010 his neck was slashed by convicted armed robber Damien Fowkes, an incident that took place two years after his transfer to HMP Frankland.

"He's up there with one of the most hated prisoners. It could have been anyone. The majority would attack him for the reputation, not because of what he has done. They will want to be the one that done in Ian Huntley," a source told the Chronicle.

"It's not the first time it's happened. It's always going to happen. If he survives it's always going to happen every few years. If he has annoyed someone really bad or someone wants to be able to say they have killed him. He's probably one of the most famous prisoners in the country."

‌



Another prison source previously described Huntley is an "up and down" person, swinging often from extreme to the next - acting the "big man" towards his fellow prisoners one moment and then before they know it becoming incredibly moody and reclusive. All while feeling sorry for himself about the length of his sentence - he won't be eligible for parole until 2042.

One horrifying anecdote from sources behind bars claims Huntley flew into a fit of rage after lags taunted him over his beloved Manchester United shirt - the same kind his victims were wearing when he killed them. Huntley later cut the shirts from their bodies and tried to hide them in a bin.

In a warped twist, his shirt was also emblazoned with the number 10 - a possible reference to the age of the girls he murdered in Soham, The Sun reported. Guards searched his cell after getting wind as his fellow inmates chanted, "Huntley, Huntley, where's your shirt?"

‌



Framed photos of Maxine Carr - the girlfriend who provided him with a false alibi - were also reportedly confiscated. A source claimed: "They're shouting insults and calling him 'sicko' and stuff. They’ve also mocked him about losing the Carr pictures. Huntley's livid. He's been going up the wall."

Meanwhile, Huntley previously pleaded with a female penpal to send him a photograph of her in a Manchester United shirt as he awaited trial. The Daily Mirror revealed how he asked the penpal three times and on one occasion told her from prison that he would be "punishing" her if she didn't do as he asked.

At one point, he tried to use a secret code to send messages to co-accused Maxine Carr, copying a tactic used by Ian Brady and Myra Hindley. In the penpal letters, just released by police who had kept them as evidence of his state-of-mind, Huntley admitted he could lose his temper with a "bang". He also wrote: "When I'm down, I'm a miserable git and when I'm cheerful I'm a barking woof woof. All I can say is that I hope my future has plenty of woof woof woof moments. God I am nuts."

News.title: 'Crocs and pyjamas ban' at major airport sparks debate over flight dress codes
News.content:
'Crocs and pyjamas ban' at major airport sparks debate over flight dress codes

A major airport sparked debate around airport dress codes when it announced it wanted to become the "world's first Crocs-free AND pyjama-free airport", and travellers have been left divided by the X post

View 4 Images The post has sparked debate about airport clothing (Image: Getty)

A major airport has ignited controversy over appropriate airport clothing with an X post declaring "We've had enough." Tampa International Airport took to X (formerly Twitter ) yesterday (February 26) with an announcement claiming it aspired to become the "world's first Crocs-free AND pajama-free airport".

‌



The post opened with the declaration "We've seen enough. We've had enough." before stating "The madness stops today." The airport took aim at travellers sporting pyjamas in broad daylight, encouraging people to have a "difficult conversation" with relatives who might be guilty of such a fashion misstep, reports the Express.

‌



While the airport went on to confirm to USA Today that the post was lighthearted, it nevertheless triggered a discussion about appropriate flying attire and whether dress codes ought to be enforced.

‌



View 4 Images Tampa International Airport later revealed its post was 'lighthearted' (Image: Getty)

Its statement explained: "Tampa International Airport regularly shares lighthearted, satirical social media content as part of our ongoing effort to engage with our followers. Today's post about 'banning' pajamas was another playful nod to day-of-travel fashion debates. We encourage our passengers to travel comfortably and appreciate our loyal followers who enjoy the online humor."

While airports typically don't enforce dress codes, there have been cases where passengers have been refused boarding or removed from planes based on their attire. In 2024, two women sporting crop tops were removed from a Spirit Airlines flight leaving Los Angeles after declining to cover up with their jumpers.

‌



In 2025, the budget carrier updated its contract of carriage, warning that travellers who are "barefoot or inadequately clothed" could face boarding refusal or removal from the aircraft. Spirit's terms and conditions specify this includes "see-through clothing; [being] not adequately covered; exposed breasts, buttocks, or other private parts".

View 4 Images Spirit Airlines recently updated its policies to ban inappropriate clothing (Image: Getty)

The airline also prohibits clothing and body art deemed "lewd, obscene, or offensive in nature" and states it may refuse boarding to passengers with "an offensive odor unless caused by a qualified disability".

‌



British airlines and airports haven't yet introduced clothing regulations, apart from suggestions to dress comfortably, though certain airport lounges do have dress codes. No1 Lounges, which operates facilities at major hubs including London Gatwick and Heathrow, states on its website: "Yes, we have a dress code in place. We ask all our guests to wear smart-casual clothing.

"Our dress code stipulates that we reserve the right to refuse admission to anyone wearing clothing which we deem to be unsuitable. This includes themed or fancy-dress outfits, clothes with slogans that may cause offence, sports shirts, beach flip flops, vests, and clothing that exposes midriffs or upper thighs.

"Our My Lounge spaces are designed to be a little more relaxed and informal, encouraging guests to dress comfortably and express their individuality. Casual clothing, trainers, flip flops, and athleisure are welcome at My Lounge." The policy does clarify, however, that unsuitable items such as fancy dress are still banned in these areas.

‌



View 4 Images Should airports enforce a dress code? (Image: Getty)

Despite its tongue-in-cheek tone, Tampa International Airport's social media post ignited discussion about appropriate flying attire. One commenter enthused: "I love this! Let's go back to the way it was in the 50's, 60's and 70's!", accompanied by vintage photographs showing impeccably dressed passengers from bygone eras.

Little-known passport rule could see you turned away at the airport READ MORE :

Another countered: "I'll dress nice again when we're not treated like cattle at the airport and on the plane." While contributor questioned: "How are you even classifying clothing as pajamas to begin with? Are sweatpants, yoga pants, children wearing soft clothes pajamas?".

Article continues below

Would you back dress codes at airports and on airplanes? Share your thoughts in the comments below.
